Henry A. Cabirac, Jr., of New
Orleans ha been named director
of the Phoenix Human Relations
Commission by William P. Reilly
chairman.


The city council approved the
appointment and a proposed an
nual salary of $l2,3l2.


He said: IA screening commit
tee carefully reviewed 40 appli-
cations for the post. MIR. Cab
irac has had excellent training
and experience in the field Of
human relations. He ha sbeen ex-
ecutive director of the New Or
leans Catholic Council on HUI
man Relations since 1861 and
at the same time wa S in charge
of the Southern Field Service of
the Catholic Conference on Inter-
racial Justice.


"He helped plan successful
compliance with the public &C
commodations section of the Civil
Rights Bill and in desegregating
Catholic schools in New Orleans
and Atlanta, Ga. He was sue
cessful in achieving harmony in
his work with white and colored
leaders in l4-state area"


Cabirac, 40, is World War
II Navy veteran, graduate Of
Tulane University and is mar
ried and has three children. He
is native of New Orleans.

R eIutions


Director N am ed

PHILADELPHIA D. Ward
Nichols, suspended bishop of the
African Methodist Episcopal
Church, was relea sed after
three man panel of judges upset
the guilty of theft charges against
him.


Bishop Nichols. of Long Island.
N. Y, had appealed his case.
He was convicted by a circuit
court on embodiment and fraud
lent annexing of $4,000 in
Guiding church monies for his
personal bank account.


The IS year old bishop was
iubiliant upon his acquittal.

SEATTLE = Little Willie John
was jailed on a murder charge.
He is accused of stabbing 24o
pound man to death during fight
at a wild interracial drinking
party.


The 1870 lb. singer, known for
his recording of Fever" had
rented the apartment during his
nightclub appearance in the city.


The stabbing resulted from the
big mans refusal to give his
seat to a young woman guest.
The victim, Kendall Roundtree
was At. His accused slayer
William Edward (Little Willie)
John is III, and 5 #, S inches.

John c. Foster, executive d.
rector of the Arizona Blue Cross
Blue Shield Plan, announced the
promotion. of Walter M. Spears,
24l8 West Wa shington, to super
visor of the Mail and Stock De-
partment.


Spears, a native of New Or
leans, La, has been with the plan
for Is years. He attended the
New Orleans YMCA School Of
Commerce and Lam son Business
College. He and his wife are
the parents of four children. He
is member Of the Church of
God in Christ.

After a three hour special
session, the Texas Dental AS
ISOLATION, voted to accept Negro
members if they are recognized
as members of local dental
groups.


This action repealed the 1861
rule which prohibited Negro den
fists from belonging to the state
group although they belonged toa
local one.


1t is reported there are ap-
proximately 100 Negro dentists
in the tate.

Mrs. Banks, o-publisher Arizona
Tribune, shows of weekly Wallace
H. Terry II, correspondent with Time Magazine.
Terry in the Valley with national international



Dental campaign.


point of general interest found when Mrs.
Terry discovered that they shared hometoWns Indianapolis
He is native New Yorker,
Indianapolis. He attended Brown University Providence
where he the first Negro editor of paper.
After receiving degree from the University Chicago
Terry ordained minister of the Disciples Christ.
He became interested relations and journalism
the staffs of the Providence Journal
polls News four years hngton
joining Time la year,


His of achievements includes being
he interviewed
Cow Orval Faubus during the days racial " Arkansas.

The decisive UictO1y Of the Democratic
Party for the presidential zee and in most
other cOngTe SS iO,a0l and state and county Of
fees throughout the nation proves that the
thinning party wielded no magic.


The defeat of the Republican Party fol-
LoaOed the doanstaH Of national ticket CON-
posed Of Senator Barry Golduutev and Rep.
William Miller, former Republican National
Panty chairman. They 1VeYe unable to in
thuence the majority of UOteYS in the nation
that peace, bT0Sbe 11ty and extended federal
programs weYe not beneficial. In re Tying too
greatly ON dis content and Wide spread Obb0Si-
ton to such important issues as the ciUil
rights act, the Tennessee Valley Authority,
and nucLe0T 1Oe0bOnS cu1t0iln1ent, Barry
GOldU0teY 1U0S Uictin1 of q NARROW and
unre0hstic platform devised by iuexbeY-
fenced advisers.


On the other hand, President johnson, one
of the 1COYld'S most 0Stute politicians, dis
played his thinning nays at every stop on his
campaign route. He en1bhaS sized the progress
Ses of the nation and made proposals that
would giue help to many areas. He remained
from the negative type of mate rial used in
cessantly by his Republican opponent


There W0s no naagician'S atund In Tuesday s
elections many excellent candidates a0eYe
supported. Some we're defeated and some
NON, but some Of the lessons learned mil
unfortunately be forgotten Within the next
four years.


Perhaps one Of the most significant facts
to remember is the failure of a back lash
vote. This byoveS that more Anne y1canS are
not disturbed ovev ne cent equality moves for
and by Negroes.


A second important fact is the large turn
out by Negro vOteTS all OUeY the nation At
last they are lea ming the importance Of the
ballot box.


The Arizona Tribune extends c0ngyutul0-
tionS to the President Johnson and Vice Pres
ident Humphrey. We all look forward to
united efforts of u0i,a1evs and losers for
greater progress in all fifty states.
